example[0]: Be careful with that vase – it’s very fragile.
definition[1]: a fragile situation is one that is weak or uncertain, and likely to become worse under pressure
example[3]: Relations between the two countries are in a fragile state.
definition[3]: if someone feels fragile they feel ill, especially because they have drunk too much alcohol
example[6]: The documents are old and very fragile.
example[8]: The seventeenth century wall hangings are extremely fragile.
definition[4]: easily damaged – used especially about things that are made from thin material and look attractive
example[10]: The plant has delicate blue flowers.
definition[5]: brittle hair, nails, bones etc have a hard surface, but they break easily, especially because they are not in good condition
example[12]: As you get older, your bones become more brittle.
example[13]: a special shampoo for dry and brittle hair
definition[6]: breakable objects must be handled carefully because they will break easily
example[14]: Put breakable objects out of the reach of children.
definition[7]: made of thin material that tears easily, or badly-made and likely to break easily
definition[8]: not strong and therefore easy to break, damage, or hurt
example[18]: The young trees are frail and need to be protected from the wind.
